TALKING POINTS: Hate Crimes Prevention Aet Event
Scheduling proposal sponsored by OPL, OPA, WHC, Leg, DPC



This is the President's bill; he first proposed it at the WH Conference on Hate Crimes on
        November 10, 1997. It is among the leading civil rights legislative priorities for the
Administration.

This White House event would bring together the bi-partisan Senate and House co-sponsors
and would also serve to highlight the increasingly broad and bi-partisan support the
legislation has in the law enforcement and civil rights communities.

We have received rcquests from major civil rights groups (the Leadership Conference and
others) and the Congressional sponsors to do an event like the one proposed in order to
continue to create momentum for the legislation.

The legislation would strengthen the ability of the Justice Department to prosecute hate crimes
based on race and religion by removing needless jurisdictional requirements and give the
Department the power to prosecute hate crimes committed because of the victim's sexual
orientation, gender, or disability.

A recent CNN/Gallup/USA Today poll found that 70 of respondents favor hate crimes laws and
that 83 and 75 , respectively, favor coverage for women and gays. MTV is planning to release
 a poll on the day of the event relating to youth and hate crimes.

The precise details of the event would be worked through with the communications team, but it
would include remarks from some combination of the following individuals: The Attorney
General; Senators Specter, Kennedy, Schumer; Congressman Conyers and others; Hate crime
survivor or family member of victim (possibly Judy Shepard); Representatives of law
enforcement community and civil rights organizations.
;.
